docs.snippet: Even after this year's Oscars, the films of Arthur Cohn still hold the record for the most won by any producer. Beginning with ''The Sky Above, the Mud Below'' (1961), Cohn productions have won six in the documentary and foreign-language categorie...
docs.lead_paragraph: Even after this year's Oscars, the films of Arthur Cohn still hold the record for the most won by any producer. Beginning with ''The Sky Above, the Mud Below'' (1961), Cohn productions have won six in the documentary and foreign-language categories. That called for a collection and last week Home Vision released the six winners and four of his other films in a boxed set of nine DVD's with a suggested retail price of $199.95. Mr. Cohn produces films of unusual variety and interest. Available for the first time on DVD, Barbara Kopple's ''American Dream,'' best documentary in 1991, follows the epic meatpackers' strike against Hormel in Austin, Minn., during the late 80's. (The film was also released today as a single DVD by Disney at $19.99.)

headline.main: A Set Surveys the Work of a Record-Setting Producer

docs.snippet: THE Super Bowl is supposed to be the biggest day of the year for advertising, but when measured against the Academy Awards this year, it seems, well, hobbit-size.    The commercials that appeared on ABC on Sunday during the broadcast of the 76th a...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Super Bowl is supposed to be the biggest day of the year for advertising, but when measured against the Academy Awards this year, it seems, well, hobbit-size. The commercials that appeared on ABC on Sunday during the broadcast of the 76th annual Academy Awards were mostly superior to the spots shown on CBS during the Super Bowl on Feb. 1. The contrast was particularly noteworthy because some companies like Anheuser-Busch, General Motors and PepsiCo advertised on both.
docs.abstract: Assessment of some of best and worst Oscar commercials presented nationally by ABC photos (M)

headline.main: A lopsided victory for Oscar, up against the Super Bowl's spots.

docs.snippet: We See Argentina For the After Party      ''This reminds me of Morton's,'' GABRIEL BYRNE said at the Entertainment Weekly Academy Awards party at Elaine's on Sunday night.    We were not sure whether he was referring to the noise level or the cele...
docs.lead_paragraph: We See Argentina For the After Party ''This reminds me of Morton's,'' GABRIEL BYRNE said at the Entertainment Weekly Academy Awards party at Elaine's on Sunday night. We were not sure whether he was referring to the noise level or the celebrity level, both of which were considerable: We saw LIZA MINNELLI, in a black tunic and pants thing that suggested that now that DAVID GEST is gone, she is eating whatever the heck she wants; CHRIS NOTH; JOHN LEGUIZAMO; ROSE McGOWAN; and TED ALLEN.
docs.abstract: Joyce Wadler Boldface Names column discusses Entertainment Weekly Academy Awards party at Elaine's restaurant in New York (M)

byline.original: By Joyce Wadler; with Paula Schwartz and Sharon Waxman

docs.snippet: Last week, with the Academy Awards days away, the designer Carolina Herrera spoke to Women's Wear Daily about Renée Zellweger, who the newspaper guessed might be wearing a Herrera gown on the red carpet. ''What Renée wears is her decision,'' Ms....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, with the Academy Awards days away, the designer Carolina Herrera spoke to Women's Wear Daily about Renée Zellweger, who the newspaper guessed might be wearing a Herrera gown on the red carpet. ''What Renée wears is her decision,'' Ms. Herrera demurred. ''I always say, 'You never know until they're in the car.' '' Well, there is no need to be coy. There was a time when designers sent multiple dresses to multiple stars, never knowing until the limo doors swung open whose glittery creation a nominee would favor. But there is too much depending on what stars wear -- millions of dollars in free publicity for designers -- to leave such decisions to chance. Increasingly, fashion houses have turned to contracts -- some informal, some written, some with an indirect financial payout -- to ensure stars' loyalty on Oscar night.
docs.abstract: More and more celebrities are formalizing their relationships with various designers and agreeing to wear only their fashions at public appearances; actor Adrien Brody, for example, wears only designs of Ermenegildo Zegna; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Experts See Risks as China Asserts Economic Power  As China increasingly welcomes multinational companies and foreign investment, many Western business executives have become positively enraptured by the company's cheap work force and its huge mar...
docs.lead_paragraph: Experts See Risks as China Asserts Economic Power As China increasingly welcomes multinational companies and foreign investment, many Western business executives have become positively enraptured by the company's cheap work force and its huge markets. But that same openness -- combined with China's vast population and military muscle -- makes it an even bigger long-term economic challenge to the United States than Japan seemed to be in the 1980's, according to a growing number of executives, economists and officials. [Page A1.]

docs.snippet: On the morning after the Academy Awards, most people, sensible people, go back to work, perhaps a little bleary-eyed from the broadcast, perhaps to claim their share of the office Oscar pool. (This was a bad year for cashing in big, since in virtu...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the morning after the Academy Awards, most people, sensible people, go back to work, perhaps a little bleary-eyed from the broadcast, perhaps to claim their share of the office Oscar pool. (This was a bad year for cashing in big, since in virtually every category the long-established favorite was the winner, and there is no point spread to beat.) Others wake up to the gray Los Angeles dawn and sort through the detritus of the weekend -- the crumpled valet parking stubs, the strange skin-care products handed out in party goody bags, the cocktail napkins stained with the grease of too many minicrabcakes -- in search of, how to say it, meaning. Go ahead and roll your eyes. The Oscars are, after all, perhaps the most lavishly and aggressively trivial event on the pop culture calendar. This year, though, was special: a plausible answer to a future trivia question about the least memorable Oscars ever.

docs.snippet: An article yesterday about the Academy Awards referred incorrectly in some copies to the nationality of Peter Jackson, who was named best director for ''The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King.'' He is from New Zealand, not Australia. The ar...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article yesterday about the Academy Awards referred incorrectly in some copies to the nationality of Peter Jackson, who was named best director for ''The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King.'' He is from New Zealand, not Australia. The article also misstated the number of times a nomination has gone to Sean Penn, who won the Oscar this year as best actor. It is four, not three. The article also misidentified the man who was kissed by Renée Zellweger after she won the Oscar for best supporting actress, in ''Cold Mountain.'' He was John Carrabino, her manager, not Bob Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax, which made the film.
docs.abstract: Correction of March 1 article about Academy Awards; best director Peter Jackson is from New Zealand; best actor Sean Penn has been nominated four times and John Carrabino, not Bob Weinstein, kissed Renee Zellweger after she won best supporting actress
docs.section_name: Movies; Corrections; New York and Region

docs.snippet: KANOWITZ--Amanda Rose. Beloved daughter of Richard and Alissa Kanowitz and a darling sister of Adam. Cherished granddaughter of Steven and Bonnie Kanowitz, Richard and Dr. Eileen Feldgus. Loving great-granddaughter of Maye Goldstein and Oscar Glic...
docs.lead_paragraph: KANOWITZ--Amanda Rose. Beloved daughter of Richard and Alissa Kanowitz and a darling sister of Adam. Cherished granddaughter of Steven and Bonnie Kanowitz, Richard and Dr. Eileen Feldgus. Loving great-granddaughter of Maye Goldstein and Oscar Glickman. Adored niece of Melissa and Cliff Karlin, Todd and Selena Fass, Amy and Steven Promislo. Dearest cousin of Jacqueline, Jenna, Marly and Rachel. Funeral services 10 a.m., Wednesday at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. KANOWITZ--Amanda Rose. The Gutterman Family and their employees offer their deepest sympathies to Steven and Bonnie Kanowitz and Richard and Alissa Kanowitz upon the tragic loss of Amanda Rose.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANOWITZ, AMANDA ROSE

docs.snippet: In something of a microcosm of ABC's fortunes this television season, the comeback of ''Who Wants To Be a Millionaire'' last week started strong in the ratings but faded as the competition stiffened.     The game show, now called ''Super Millionai...
docs.lead_paragraph: In something of a microcosm of ABC's fortunes this television season, the comeback of ''Who Wants To Be a Millionaire'' last week started strong in the ratings but faded as the competition stiffened. The game show, now called ''Super Millionaire'' to reflect the $10 million jackpot, still performed better than almost everything else on ABC's schedule. It was the highest-rated program on the network each of the five nights it was on last week, although none of the shows matched Sunday's promising performance, when it was the highest-rated show on any network.
docs.abstract: Super Millionaire, ABC's new version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, starts strong in ratings on Feb 22 but fades as competition stiffens; still performs better than almost everything else on ABC's schedule; photo (M)

headline.main: 'Super Millionaire' Helps ABC But Doesn't Provide Mega-Payoff
'The Lord of the Rings' Ties Oscar Record
